questions.question: Question 1: What type of nerve is the facial nerve?
questions.explanation:
The facial nerve is a mixed cranial nerve which contains both sensory and motor part. It is the 7th 
cranial nerve.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a component of the facial nerve?
questions.explanation:
The general somatic efferent is not a component of the facial nerve. 210 
Sold by @itachibot Components of the facial nerve: • Special visceral efferent - motor to muscles of facial expression (derived from branchial arches, 
hence special visceral and not general somatic like the other muscles) • General visceral efferent - secretomotor to lacrimal and submandibular glands • Special visceral afferent - taste from anterior 2/3rd tongue • General somatic afferent - general sensations from pinna, external auditory canal, and tympanic 
membrane.

questions.question:
Question 3: In a patient with an acoustic neuroma involving the sensory division of the facial nerve, the 
Hitzelberger sign was positive. What is the other name for this nerve?
questions.explanation:
The sensory division of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg. The facial nerve is a 
mixed nerve having the motor and a sensory root. Hitzelberger sign refers to hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in acoustic neuroma due to 
the compression of the facial nerve. Option A: Jacobson’s nerve - the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial 
nerve). It is associated with glomus tympanicum. Option B: Arnold’s nerve - the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve). Option D: Herring’s nerve - the carotid sinus branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial 
nerve). 211 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: You are performing the cranial nerve examination in a patient with a stroke. You noticed a 
loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. What is this sensation carried by?
questions.explanation:
The taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the special visceral afferent 
of the facial nerve via chorda tympani nerve. The taste sensation from the hard and soft palate is also carried by the facial nerve via the greater 
superficial petrosal nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with the following findings is presented to you. Where is the motor nucleus of the 
involved cranial nerve is located?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows left-sided lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy and the motor nucleus is 
located in the pons. It is located along with abducens and vestibulocochlear nerve nuclei.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following best describes the course of the facial nerve in the pons?

options.a: It hooks around the 8th nerve nucleus
options.b: It hooks around the 6th nerve nucleus
options.d: It exits the pons at ponto-pyramidal junction

questions.explanation:
The facial nerve in the pons hooks around the 6th (abducens) nerve nucleus. It exits the pons ventrally at the pontomedullary (ponto-olivary) junction. It then runs in the 
cerebellopontine angle to reach the internal auditory meatus. 212 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: 206 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is false about the first genu of the facial nerve?

options.a: Contains a ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland
options.b: Gives the first branch of the facial nerve
options.c: Lies on the posterior wall of the middle ear
options.d: Between the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus and the geniculate ganglion.

questions.explanation:
The 1st genu of the facial nerve lies on the medial wall of the middle ear and not posterior wall. It is formed at the geniculate ganglion when the facial nerve from the fundus of the internal 
acoustic meatus takes a turn posteriorly. Then the facial nerve continues as a tympanic or 
horizontal segment. It homes the geniculate ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland (via greater superficial petrosal 
nerve). It gives off the first branch of the facial nerve.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is true for the 2nd genu of the facial nerve?

options.b: It gives the second branch of the facial nerve
options.c: It lies on the inferior wall of the middle ear
options.d: It is at the junction of 3rd and 4th intratemporal segments

questions.explanation:
213 
Sold by @itachibot The 2nd genu of the facial nerve lies at the junction of the 3rd and the 4th 
intratemporal segments, between the tympanic and the mastoid segments. The 2nd genu of the facial nerve is formed where the horizontal facial nerve takes a turn inferiorly 
at the junction between the medial and posterior walls of the middle ear. It continues as the vertical segment of the facial nerve behind the posterior wall of the middle ear. 
It does not contain a ganglion and does not give any branches. The course of the facial nerve has 3 parts- • Intracranial • Intratemporal • Extracranial. Intratemporal part of the facial nerve has 4 segments- • Meatal • Labyrinthine • Tympanic/horizontal • Mastoid/vertical segments. Option A: Gasserian ganglion is present in the trigeminal nerve. Option B: The temporal segment of the facial nerve ends with the 2nd genu. The nerve then 
passes vertically downward to form the mastoid segment. The 2nd branch of facial nerve (nerve to 
stapedius) arises from this segment close to the level of 2nd genu and not from the 2nd genu.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
questions.explanation:
The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 
mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm). 214 
Sold by @itachibot The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve 
takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest 
diameter and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation 
can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

questions.question:
Question 10: In the examination of a patient with facial nerve palsy, the Schirmer test was positive. 
Involvement of which of the following branches of the facial nerve is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Involvement of the greater superficial petrosal nerve causes a decrease in lacrimation, detected by 
the Schirmer test. It is the first branch of the facial nerve and arises from the geniculate ganglion. It carries 
secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland and the glands of nasal mucosa and palate. 215 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: 207 
Sold by @itachibot A young man who underwent surgery for chronic suppurative otitis media presented with a 
loss of taste sensation. Which segment of the facial nerve gives rise to the involved branch?
questions.explanation:
The injury to chorda tympani nerve produces loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the 
tongue and it arises from the mastoid or vertical segment of the facial nerve. Chorda tympani nerve carries the taste sensation from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. It is a branch 
of the facial nerve arising from the mastoid/vertical segment after the nerve to stapedius before 
exiting the stylomastoid foramen. It relays in the nucleus of tractus solitarius.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is the most common site for congenital dehiscence of the fallopian 
canal?
questions.explanation:
The congenital dehiscence (absence of bony cover) of the fallopian canal of the facial nerve occurs 
most commonly in the tympanic or horizontal segment over the oval window. 216 
Sold by @itachibot It is the most common anomaly of the facial canal. A dehiscent nerve is prone to injury at the time 
of surgery. It gets easily compressed or inflamed in mastoid and middle ear infections.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve?
questions.explanation:
The frontal branch is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve. The five terminal branches of the facial nerve are: • Temporal • Zygomatic • Buccal • Mandibular • Cervical The extratemporal course of the facial nerve starts at the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the 
temporal bone and runs anteriorly to enter the substance of the parotid gland. Here it divides into 2 main terminal trunks, the temporofacial and the cervicofacial. These further 
divide and re-anastomose to give the five terminal branches.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient with an acoustic neuroma at the cerebellopontine angle presents with a facial nerve 
palsy. Which of the following muscles will not be paralyzed in this case?
questions.explanation:
Anterior belly of digastric is not paralyzed in facial nerve palsy. Muscles supplied by facial nerve: • Nerve to stapedius - stapedius muscle. • Posterior auricular nerve - muscles of the pinna and the occipital belly of occipitofrontalis. 217 
Sold by @itachibot • Muscular branches - stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric. • Terminal branches - muscles of facial expression.

questions.question: Question 15: The facial nerve is not supplied by which of the following vessels?
questions.explanation:
Facial artery does not supply the facial nerve Vascular Supply of facial nerve: • Anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the cerebellopontine angle • Labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the 
internal auditory canal • Superficial petrosal artery, a branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies geniculate ganglion 
and the adjacent region • Stylomastoid artery, a branch of the posterior auricular artery supplies the mastoid segment.

questions.question:
Question 16: You are an ENT resident assisting on a modified radical mastoidectomy in a patient with 
cholesteatoma. Which of the following landmarks will not help you to identify the facial 
nerve?
questions.explanation:
Posterior semicircular canal is not used as a surgical landmark to identify the facial nerve. Surgical Landmarks of the facial nerve for middle ear and mastoid surgery: • Processus cochleariformis - It demarcates the geniculate ganglion which lies just anterior to it. 
The tympanic segment of the nerve starts at this level. • Oval window and horizontal semicircular canal - The horizontal segment of the facial nerve runs 
above the oval window (stapes) and below the horizontal/lateral semicircular canal. • Short process of incus - The vertical segment of the facial nerve lies medial to the short process 
of incus at the level of aditus. • Pyramid - The vertical segment of the facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and the posterior 
tympanic sulcus. 218 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: While performing a parotidectomy, which of the following landmarks would you use to 
identify the facial nerve?
questions.explanation:
Tragus is used as a surgical landmark to identify facial nerve in parotid surgery. Surgical landmarks of the facial nerve for parotid surgery: • Tragal pointer - triangular inferior portion of the tragus. The main trunk lies 1 cm deep to it. • Tympanomastoid suture - the main trunk lies 6-8 mm deep to it. • Styloid process - the nerve lies lateral to it • Posterior belly of digastric attachment at the digastric groove - the nerve can be found emerging 
from the stylomastoid foramen under the muscle but lateral to the styloid process. 219 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: While performing mastoid exploration, which of the following is not useful in preventing the 
injury to the facial nerve?

options.d: Innervation by fibres from prefrontal cortex

questions.explanation:
A larger burr is used to prevent facial nerve injury in the mastoid exploration and not a smaller 
burr. Measures to reduce facial nerve injury during mastoid exploration: • Good anatomical knowledge • Working parallel to the nerve, never at an angle. • Use the biggest burr available. Smaller burrs are more harmful. • Constant irrigation prevents thermal injury • Granulations present over the facial nerve are best left alone. • Good magnification. 220 
Sold by @itachibot Facial Nerve Disorders
